Award.AwardTitle: Facility Support: AfricaArray - Advancing Earth Science Research and Education with an Interdisciplinary Network in Africa
Award.AbstractNarration: AfricaArray (www.africaarray.org) is a multifaceted initiative focused on developing a pool of diverse and talented undergraduate and graduate students for the geoscience workforce in the U.S. and Africa through linked research and training programs. Launched in 2005 with support from government, academic and industry partners, AfricaArray now supports three coupled activities, 1) a multidisciplinary observatory network in Africa, 2) a graduate training program for U.S. and African students focusing on research in Africa, and 3) a program to enhance diversity in the geosciences in the U.S. and Africa. This grant supports the operation and maintenance of the observatory network, which provides seismic, GPS and weather data openly to the science community. The network consists of 44 observatories spanning 17 countries in eastern, southern and western Africa. All but one of the observatories houses seismic sensors, and by the end of 2012, twenty-one of the observatories will also be equipped with GPS receivers and automated weather stations. The seismic data are archived and distributed by the IRIS data management center, and the GPS and weather data are archived and distributed by the UNAVCO data management center. Data from the network are being used for solid earth and atmospheric research projects by a wide range of students, faculty and researchers worldwide, including a number of underrepresented minority students in the U.S.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The goals of this project were to support the operations and maintenance of the AfricaArray observatory network.  The network consists of 53 observatories in 17 African countries.  Twenty-four of the observatories are equipped with seismic, GPS and weather sensors.  The others are equipped with just seismic sensors.  The network is a research network, with most of the stations operating autonomously.  The stations are visited every few months to download data and perform routine maintenance.   Support from NSF was used to maintain and operate the observatories. The operations and maintenance of the network consists of several parts.  At the core are efforts by the in-country station operators to download data and perform routine maintenance on the stations.  Funding from this grant supported a roving technician based in South Africa who was responsible for working with the station operators to troubleshoot and fix problems with the equipment.  Funding was also used to repair equipment and support technicians to attend the annual AfricaArray workshop in South Africa, where they received training on equipment operation and maintenance.   The project principal investigator provided oversight of all aspects of network operations. Data from the network have been archived at the IRIS and UNAVCO data management centers and are openly available. The data fill in a large gap in global seismic and GPS data coverage.  As such, the data are used widely for global seismic and geodetic studies.  The data are also being used widely by the research community to investigate anomalous deep mantle structure beneath eastern and southern Africa and continental rifting and plateau uplift that is related to the deep mantle structure.  Data from the network have been used by many graduate students, postdocs and faculty for research, and thus the network has positively impacted the geoscience workforce in the U.S. as well as in many African countries.
